awd_titl_txt: Mappings and Measures in Sub-Riemannian and Metric Spaces
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to investigate geometry and analysis in spaces with rough or fractal structure.  The project focuses especially on spaces which are poorly described by classical Euclidean language, such as fractals and sub-Riemannian spaces.  The latter occur as mathematical models for problems in robotics, neurobiology, celestial mechanics and other physical systems.  In each of these models, the underlying geometry is inherently nonsmooth. The proposed research will consequently contribute to developing the mathematical framework which simultaneously underlies a variety of physical applications. On the geometric side, nonsmooth notions of curvature will be studied.  Curvature is a fundamental concept in modern geometry.  For instance, general relativity predicts that curvature is the primary geometric feature of space responsible for gravity.  Nonsmooth generalizations of curvature and their relationship to the structure of measures will also be studied.  Measure theory is a wide-ranging mathematical generalization of fundamental concepts of length, area, and volume.  Finally, analysis refers to the dynamic properties of transformations acting between spaces. Since the classical Newton--Leibniz theory of the derivative is not well-adapted to transformations of nonsmooth spaces, there is currently significant interest in developing a new analytic toolkit to extend the machinery of calculus beyond its usual context.  The principle investigator will continue to train graduate students, postdocs and early-career researchers.  Results of this research program will be disseminated via talks at conferences and workshops, publication of journal articles, and exposition for a general mathematical audience.  The PI is currently coauthoring a graduate textbook on analysis in nonsmooth spaces.  The ongoing preparation of this book will be coordinated with advances in the field, including those obtained as part of this research program.

The project concerns the geometry of measures and submanifolds in, and mappings between, sub-Riemannian manifolds.  Three coordinating themes will be considered.  The first set of problems concerns density of measures and the geometry of submanifolds.  The main goal is a sub-Riemannian analog of a celebrated theorem of David Preiss characterizing rectifiability (a measure-theoretic notion of smoothness) via densities.  This line of investigation will extend to the sub-Riemannian setting some fundamental aspects of Euclidean geometric measure theory tied to notions of curvature for submanifolds.  The primary methodology for this investigation involves the approximation of sub-Riemannian spaces by Riemannian spaces, and an analysis of the limiting behavior of geometric quantities in the Riemannian approximations.  The second theme concerns iteration of conformal and quasiregular mappings.  Such iterative schemes provide a basic combinatorial model for fractal objects. They arise naturally in both hyperbolic geometry and number theory.  Building on his previous work for similarity mappings, the principle investigator will extend the analysis to conformal mappings.  The goal is a detailed description of the geometry of self-conformal limit sets in sub-Riemannian spaces and natural measures on such sets. Finally, the principle investigator will study the type problem for sub-Riemannian quasiregular mappings. The goal here is to understand both the flexibility of quasiregular mappings as well as inherent geometric obstructions to their construction.  The principle investigator will also investigate new constructions of Sobolev mappings inducing optimal measure and dimension distortion, as well as criteria for the density of Lipschitz mappings in spaces of Sobolev mappings with sub-Riemannian targets.  The principle investigator will take advantage of his prior expertise in all of the aforementioned areas, as well as the latest advances in related fields, to pursue answers to the proposed problems.  The proposed research will have a broad impact; it addresses a wide range of questions at the intersection of different mathematical areas. The principle investigator will use this broad framework to identify specific problems suitable for beginning graduate students and postdocs.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit: The historical origins of the mathematical discipline of analysis lie in the classical theories of differential and integral calculus for functions of one or several variables. In its modern incarnation, analysis considers transformations acting on and between curved surfaces and higher-dimensional objects, as well as more abstract geometric structures, poorly described by the classical language of Euclidean geometry. The interplay between the static, geometric structure of the ambient environment and the dynamical behavior of transformations acting between such environments is a key theme in mathematical analysis.
 
This project investigated analysis and geometry in spaces with rough or fractal structure. More specifically, it considered the effect of mappings on the sizes of subsets and on the structure of measures, including the long-term, or asymptotic, behavior of collections of mappings. The class of conformal mappings in a specific nonsmooth environment (the sub-Riemannian Heisenberg group) was studied in detail. Conformal mappings preserve shapes of objects while allowing for arbitrary distortion of scale and size. Among the results obtained were a rigidity theorem for sub-Riemannian conformal mappings (clarifying the extent to which the usual definition of conformality can be weakened), and a series of results on the structure and complexity of limit sets obtained by iteration of families of conformal mappings.
 
The discipline known as measure theory provides mathematical generalizations for foundational geometric concepts such as length, area, and volume. Geometric measure theory investigates the interplay between the geometry of the underlying environment, the behavior of mappings between spaces, and the structure and function of measures defined thereon. Geometric measure theory in the sub-Riemannian Heisenberg group was a second major focus in the project. One of the main results obtained was a classification theorem for well-behaved measures in the Heisenberg group. This classification was completed via the simultaneous and independent publication of two papers, one (supported by this grant) describing the local geometric structure of the sets on which such measures are supported, and the other (by a colleague of the PI, not supported by this grant) identifying the algebraic character of those supporting sets.
 
The geometry of the boundary of a region is critical for understanding a host of mathematical and physical phenomena. Of particular importance is the notion of boundary curvature, which controls how surface area on a curved surface deviates from its flat counterpart, how volumes of tubular neighborhoods of regions grow, and how heat flows across a separating barrier. Each of these applications was considered in the sub-Riemannian Heisenberg group, with respect to a newly defined notion of intrinsic surface curvature. The results on the structure of well-behaved measures, described in the previous paragraph, made essential use of this new notion of curvature, restricted to the smooth surfaces on which such measures are supported.
 
In summary, the project resulted in a new understanding of the interplay among the theories of mappings between spaces, sets and measures defined in spaces, and geometric properties of the boundaries of such spaces (most notably, curvature) in a geometric environment lying outside of the realm of classically studied smooth objects.
 
Broader impacts: During the tenure of the award, six graduate students and one postdoc conducted research under the supervision of the former PI. All of these graduate students but one have by now completed their PhD and obtained a subsequent position, either in academia or in industry; at the time of preparation of this report the remaining student (co-mentored by the former PI and the current PI) was in the process of writing up his dissertation. In addition, the postdoc in question, who collaborated with the former PI on questions related to curvature, geometry, and heat flow in the sub-Riemannian Heisenberg group, successfully obtained a subsequent faculty position.
 
In addition, the former PI gave 19 talks on research conducted under this award at a wide variety of conferences and other professional gatherings. These talks included a three lecture short course delivered at Texas A&M University in July 2016, a seminar talk at Princeton University in April 2017, a workshop at the University of Warwick, U.K. in July 2017, two conferences at the University of Helsinki, Finland in June 2018, and a conference at the Simons Center for Geometry and Physics, Stony Brook University, in March 2020.
 
Finally, the former PI co-organized two virtual conferences in the field of nonsmooth geometry and analysis in 2020 and 2021. These events contributed to maintaining collaborations and professional connections during the COVID era for researchers working in the field. One of these conferences, held under the auspices of the American Mathematical Society through their Mathematical Research Communities program, facilitated the development of new professional connections and research opportunities for a group of approximately two dozen early-career researchers working at a variety of institutions across the U.S.
